title.narrative: Public Financial Managment Capacity Building II
Public Financial Mangagement Capacity Building II

description.narrative:
Public Financial Management for Institutional Strengthening (PFMRIS) projektet är ett resultat från en begäran av Liberianska regeringen till Världsbanken om ett uppföljningsprojekt till Integrated Public Financial Management Programme (IPFMRP), som avslutades 30 juni 2017.
Det föreslagna PFMRIS är ett omfattande reformprojekt inom offentlig finansiell styrning i Liberia, med en total volym på 24.3 miljoner USD. Världsbanken finansierar 19 miljoner USD, det svenska bidraget uppgår till 50 miljoner SEK (cirka USD 5.3 miljoner). Europeiska Unionen planerar även stöd till projektet om cirka USD 2 miljoner.
Projektet bygger på lärdomarna från IPFMRP, med följande huvudkomponenter: 1) Ökad inhemsk intäktsmobilisering, 2) Stabilisera och stärka finansiell kontroll och system, 3) Förbättra den offentliga sektorns förmåga till ökad transparens och ansvarstagande, 4) Förbättrade PFM-system i hälsa- och utbildningssektorerna, 5) Projektledning.
Projektet bidrar till genomförande av prioriteringar som återfinns i Liberias utvecklingsplan, the Pro-Poor Agenda for Prosperity and Development (PAPD), och den nationella PFM Strategin- och handlingsplanen. PAPD's fokusområden inkluderar att utveckla en transparent och effektiv offentlig förvaltning, motarbeta korruption, främja en genuin en transparant privatsektor och att förbättra mänsklig utveckling.

The Public Financial Management for Institutional Strengthening (PFMRIS) project follows the Government of Liberia's request to the World Bank for a continued support to the Integrated Public Financial Management Programme (IPFMRP), which closed on June 30, 2017.
The PFMRIS is a comprehensive PFM reform project in Liberia, with a total volume of USD 24.3 million. The World Bank financing is 19 million USD and the Swedish contribution is SEK 50 million (approximately USD 5.3 million). The European Union plans to support to the project for the amount of USD 2 million.
The project builds on the lessons of the IPFMRP, with the following main components: 1) Enhancing domestic revenue mobilization, 2) Stabilizing and strengthening performance of financial controls and systems, 3) Improving public sector capacity for enhanced oversight and accountability, 4) Improving PFM systems in selected sectors, 5) Project management.
The project aims to support priorities identified in the national development agenda, the Pro-Poor Agenda for Prosperity and Development (PAPD), and the national PFM Strategy and Action Plan. The PAPD aims, among other things, to establish an accountable and effective public sector, combat corruption, promote an honest and transparent private sector, and improve human development.

The Public Financial Management Reform for Institutional Strengthening (PFMRIS) project has the aim to support government ambitions in reforms within the public financial management in Liberia. The rationale of the proposed project is to support Government of Liberia (GoL) achieve its Public Finance Management Reform Strategy and Action Plan (2017-2020) in improving systems, processes, and practices in the PFM sector. The Project Development Objective (PDO) for the proposed project is to improve domestic revenue mobilization systems, and strengthen financial control and accountability in public finances.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sweden Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and International Development Association

description.narrative: Operating a complex PFM reform project in a low capacity environment is challenging. This was also one of the key risk areas that the Embassy looked at closely amongst other high risk factors. The latest implementation mission of the project (aide memoire authored by the WB) suggested that progress has been made since the previous PFMRIS mission in September 2020, as evidenced by the fact that most of the contracting has been undertaken, whereas the main focus of the September mission was on problems with contracting processes and suppliers. Currently the majority of contracts have been signed, although the PPCC and e-procurement are lagging behind. Other components that were implemented at a too slow pace were those related to PPCC and IAA. However, there still appear to be significant issues with the specification and/implementation of some of these contracts, particularly related to the Intergrated Financial Management Information System (IFMIS) and Freebalance and also the implementation of some key activities which are discussed below. Nevertheless, 62% of project funds have been disbursed and 90% of funds committed, with the WB suggesting that there is scope for the project to close earlier than 2024. Overall the implementation mission of March 2021 raised concerns about the political will of the GoL to undertake PFM reforms and the ability of the WB to effectively manage the project. It is notable that from the GoL side they have not made progress in some of the key areas that are important for PFM reform. The implementation of the IFMIS system and the budget module in particular, have progressed slowly and were areas where the was little progress in the previous phase of the project. Similarly, with IFMIS Civil Service Module and payroll migration - there appears to be little urgency, with currently no clear timeframe outlining when this process will be completed. In all these areas the GoL does not appear able or possibly willing to give a clear explanation for this lack of progress. On the other hand, many of the systems and processes that the GoL is seeking to implement are technically challenging, particularly in a low capacity environment. The GoL also does not seem to consider it necessary to undertake activities as agreed in previous missions or project agreements. A different process for payroll verification has been established, the removal of the PMU project manager was decided without agreement or notification to the WB, while the budget module was confirmed as active when in practice it was not. The latter is particularly worrying as there is a pattern in missions of the PMU and early interviewees stating that activities have moved forward or have been implemented, only to find out in later interviews that this is not the case or for the situation to be so confused it is difficult to tell what the actual situation is. Often, progress of these technical PFM reform components are linked to disbursements from the PFMRIS project, which is even more worrying from a donor perspective. This suggests that rather than push ahead with complex reforms that the GoL is clearly struggling to implement, a better approach may be to slow the project down and recalibrate, with closer engagement with implementing agencies to ensure they can deliver effectively, rather than the current approach which seems to be focused on disbursement.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
